div.head: Plates
div.p:
svasti śrīmat-piṣṭapurāT. svāmīi-mahāsena-pādānudhyātānāṁ
hāriti-putrāṇāṁ mānavya-sagotrāṇāṁ kura
māra-svāmi-vara-labdha-raājyānāṁ śrīmac-cālukyānām aāśvame
dha-yaājinām anvaye mahodadhau Amr̥ta yiIva bhūta-trāṇā
yāa saṁbhūtaḥ kīrttivarmmā. tasya putras tiat-pādānudhyātaḥ śakti-traya-sa
māsādita-varāha-ḷlāṁchano yathaiva jagati sat-kīrty-abhilaksṣito nānā
-yuddha-vijayiī prir̥dthiśviīpati-makuṭa-maṇi-mayūkhea-khacita-pā
dāravinda-yugalaḥ śrīmān makaradhvajo viṣṇour ivāparo viṣṇu
vardhana-māahārājeḥaḥ. tasya putras tat-pādānudhyāto mahośva
la-siddhi-paryya-dhama-bhvavya siṅgha yiyirva vikraāntaḥ śrī-jayasiṅgha-valla
bha-mahāraājeo mātā-pitr̥-puṇyāvbhivr̥ddhaye guntapura-vaāstavyā
ya bhūtisvaāmi-caturvbhvedi-pautrāya gonvāyine poḷasvā
mi-putrāya kautsa-sagotrāya dvivedāya svāmiśarmmaṇe kr̥
ṣṇa-berṇṇāyā Uttara-taṭae nātāvāḍi-viṣaye viḷeṣṭi nāma
grāmam āgrahārī-kr̥tvā sarvva-bādhā-sparihāreṇa Udaka-pūrvveṇa
prattaM||

viditam astu searvva-viṣaya-vāsīināṁ AsmaTd-bhr̥tyānāñ ca
sarvviadaā sva-dharmmāo rakṣaṇiīyaḥ sarvva-dharmmāa-śāstra-vidbhī rājabhi
s. tatra śrī-brahmaṇāpi coktaM

app.note: The reading and emendation are identical in the KPS's edition; I assume the actual reading may be svāmī-.

KPS's reading seems suspect here. I know of no parallel for such a phrase in any related grant. I wonder if the correct reading might be kauśikī-prasāda-vara, in which case only the word order of a very standard phrase has been changed.

My reconstruction is extremely tentative here. KPS's reading and emendation do not appear satisfactory, and the dynasty's name does not seem to be mentioned anywhere else, so it may have appeared here. If the name was omitted, then the reading of this locus may perhaps have been śrī-vallabhānām.

Since KPM do not emend to yājināṁ, I suspect that the ṇ in their edition is a typo. I further suspect that their reading cātraya (which may be a misprint instead of chātraya) is mistaken, and the plate probably has m anvaye (or characters derivable through scribal error from that) at this locus.

I do not understand KPM's emendation of mahodadho to mahodadhā. If my restoration of the preceding word as anvaye is correct, then the most logical reading here is mahodadhau, which requires little or no emendation. It is also possible that the composer's intent was mahodadheḥ Amr̥ta.
KPS's edition has a macron over the t in ānudhyta; I assume ānudhyāta was intended.

My "reading" is a desperate guess here. All I am sure of is that I cannot interpret KPS's reading, nor the purpose of their emendation. I believe that the string deva vo may have been intended for deva(vo), i.e. an emendation of deva to devo, but this does not help.
I cannot interpret KPS's reading, nor their emendation. I emend differently, on the assumption that they show the received reading correctly.

I am unable to make any sense of this string and therefore print the received text to the letter as reported by KPS. There are likely to be both reading errors and typographic ones in this string. KPS emend as follows: maheśvara-siddhi-paryyanta-dharma-bhvavya, which is still unintelligible. The actual text may perhaps include mahojvalodadhi-paryyanta, mahī-sthalodadhi-paryyanta or catur-udadhi-paryyanta, but I cannot offer a meaningful conjecture that would cover the whole of this string.

I am unable to improve on this reported reading. KPS emend to kānvāyine, possibly understood to mean the same as kāṇvāyanāya, which I cannot exclude. I could also imagine that the text (or the intent) was gosvāmine.
KPR's text is literally svāmiśarmmaṇ(o*) here, which perhaps means that they read svāmiśarmmaṇa and emend to svāmiśarmmaṇo.
KPR's text is vāsī(si)ṇ(ne) with a macron over the opening parenthesis of (ne). I assume that their reading is ṇā.
I hazard the guess that the received text may have involved a final T followed by bh. Whether or not this is true, the intent must clearly have been asmad-.

I believe KPS's emendation was meant to be sarvva-vidha, but this is very invasive and does not yield a coherent text. My emendation is more parsimonious, but I am not entirely satisfied with my own reconstruction of the sentence. Assuming that it is largely correct, this particular word may also have been sarvvathā.
I emend tentatively, not being fully satisfied with my reconstruction of the sentence.

KPS emend in the body of their edition to -vidājñāpta (which is not intelligible to me), and then re-emend in a footnote attached to gratpa, which says, The word is unnecessary. Read as ājñaptirasya.. I feel certain that the ājñapti, recorded in his proper place at the end, would not be mentioned here. Nonetheless, I emend only tentatively, not being fully satisfied with my reconstruction of the sentence.

I am slightly more confident of this "reading" than of those in the previous line. Perhaps śrī-vyāsenāpi is also possible, but it is much harder to believe that this latter was misread as grammāgraṣi by KPS. I certainly do not consider KPS's emendation (which they take to be the name of the ājñapti, see the previous note) acceptable. For admonitory verses (possibly) attributed to Brahmā, see the Cendalūr Plates of Maṅgi Yuvarāja.
KPS actually print dācḥ at the beginning of line 19. Since they do not emend, I suppose the plates have the expected reading.

KPS print these words in square brackets with an asterisk, which I would expect to indicate characters omitted in the original. I believe, mainly on the basis of the next entry, that it is more likely that they are present and unclear or wholly illegible.

KPS print these words in square brackets with an asterisk, which I would expect to indicate characters omitted in the original. I believe it is more likely that they are present and unclear or wholly illegible, since iti is not normally added here, so they would not have supplied it if part of the stanza had been omitted from the plate. However, see also the note to vaseT in line 22
I present the original reading as reported by KPS.

Provided that the reading is correct, KPS's emendation is plausible, though I do not know of such a variant of this stanza. Given that line 25, as printed by KPS, consists only of seven characters, it may well be that this is not a line at all, but two or more interlinear additions meant to be read somewhere else.
According to KPS, this word is redundant. It is, however, required for the metre, whatever the correct reading and the composer's intent may have been.
I cannot interpret KPS's emendation. The verse is badly garbled, so my own emendation may well be off the mark.

Most of this line is my conjectural suggestion. KPS's edition prints, literally, śrīma
yaṁ-āsādhu ja vanāvagamya.

KPS note only that The metre and language are defective. I strongly doubt the correctness of their reading, but cannot offer a plausible restoration. I suspect that the name of the executor is part of this string. The emendation kaṭaka would be appropriate to the context, but it is no less unmetrical than kuṭku. The form kaḍa-rāja may have been used here, e.g. as Ājñaptir asyāḥ kaḍa-rāja. This form is not attested as far as I know, but compare kaḍa-eṟeya in the Jaḷayūru grant of Viṣṇuvardhana III and kaḍeya-rāja in the Bezvāḍa plates and Moga grant of Bhīma I, noting especially that in the Bezvāḍa plates, kaḍeya is used in place of two syllables of an anuṣṭubh stanza.

KPS believe that the engraver of the grant was named Lokanetra. They may have understood samullayati to stand for samullikhita or a similar word. The text as read and emended by them is incorrect both metrically and semantically, so I cannot accept their interpretation. I do not find loka-netra likely to be a name and believe that the stanza is a coherent one that speaks only about the executor. Nonetheless, my own restoration is only tentative.

div.head: Plates
div.p: The text of these plates has been tentatively reconstructed on the basis of KPS’s substandard edition. The accuracy of the translation is consequently low. Translations of segments where I conjecturally override the text reported by KPS are marked as uncertain, but there may well be errors in my translation of other passages as well.Greetings from majestic Piṣṭapura. In the lineage of the majestic Cālukyas, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by the Lord Mahāsena, who are the sons of Hāriti, who are of the Mānavya gotra, who have attained kingship through the boon of Lord Kumāra,I have strong doubts about the correctness of the reading of this phrase; see the apparatus to line 2 who perform the Aśvamedha sacrifice, there arose Kīrtivarman for the salvation of living beings, as nectar amr̥ta arose in the great ocean for the salvation of living beigns. His son, deliberately appointed as successor by him, was King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana, the majestic Crocodile-bannered love god makaradhvaja resembling another Viṣṇu, who acquired the Boar emblem by means of his three powers śakti-traya, who was likewise recognised among the people for his just reputation, victorious in diverse battles, whose two lotus feet are set with rays from the gemstones on the crowns of kings. His son, deliberately appointed as successor by him, namely His Majesty King mahārāja Jayasiṁha, I am unable to reconstruct the text here. It may have said something about Jayasiṁha’s fame extending to the oceans. See the apparatus to line 9. who is courageous like a lion siṁha, in order to increase his mother’s and father’s merit, has given the village named Viḷeṣṭi, located on the northern bank of the river Kr̥ṣṇa-beṇṇā in Nātavāḍi district viṣaya converted into a rent-free holding agrahāra by a remission of all burdens, to the grandson of the caturvedin Bhūtisvāmin, the son of Poḷasvāmin, namely the dvivedin Svāmiśarman of the Kautsa gotra, a I cannot interpret the reported reading gonvāyine; see the apparatus to line 12. The word may describe either Svāmiśarman (if the case ending is correct) or his father Poḷasvāmin (on the basis of its position in the sentence). residing in Guntapura, the donation being sanctified by a libation of water.

Let this be known to all residents of the district and to our Jayasiṁha’s officials bhr̥tya. All kings learned in the legal treatises dharma-śāstra must always safeguard their own righteousness sva-dharma.I reconstruct this sentence tentatively; see the apparatus notes to line 17. If my reconstruction is largely correct, then the purport of the text is that future kings who might consider revoking this grant made by Jayasiṁha should refrain from doing so in order not to acquire demerit and a bad reputation. In this connection, the Lord Brahmā too has said:
A donor of land rejoices in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved former grants. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.

Stanzas I and IV are repetitions of stanzas I and II, for no clear reason.A donor of land rejoices in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved former grants. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit/reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
O Yudhiṣṭhira, diligently preserve land that has been donated, whether by yourself or another. O best of land-possessors, preserving a grant is superior to making a grant.

What decent man would ever partake again of those donations given by kings in the past to generate merit dharma, wealth artha and fame, which are now comparable to discarded garlands or vomit?I translate the standard text of this stanza. The first hemistich may have been inscribed with errors, or with an unusual variant of this verse. See the apparatus to lines 25 and 26.

The executor ājñapti of this decree is the castellan Kaṇḍi, a foundation of proper order dharma, a wishing-tree for subjects, majestic yet also approachable by virtuous men, who always brightens the eyes of the populace.This stanza is tentatively reconstructed and translated; see the apparatus to lines 28 and 29.
Very unusually, both sides of the first plate are inscribed.

Reported in 23A/1990-918 with some further details at 3-4. Edited from inked impressions by Madhav N. Katti and C. A. Padmanabha Sastry (), without facsimiles and without translation. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on the published edition. However, this edition contains such an inordinate number of typographic (or other) mistakes, that duplicating it to the letter would serve no purpose, and in some cases the intent of the editors cannot be reconstructed. My edition therefore shows my conjectures of what the actual reading of the plates may be and how that should in my opinion be emended. Every locus where my "reading" of the assumed original diverges from the printed edition is marked up as unclear and tentatively in my edition, whereas loci marked as unclear by the original editors are shown here as unclear, but confidently read. My apparatus cites the printed edition where I deviate from it in a major way or where my conjecture is uncertain, but I silently correct some obvious typos, ignore some nonsensical emendations, and apply my own segmentation.
